title: 109_hr4844
content: The "Federal Election Integrity Act of 2006" requires voters to provide photo identification. The "Federal Election Integrity Act of 2006" mandates voters to present photo identification when voting in person for a Federal office. The "Federal Election Integrity Act of 2006" requires individuals voting in person for a Federal office to present a government-issued, current, and valid photo identification, or proof of United States citizenship for elections held after November 2010. The "Federal Election Integrity Act of 2006" mandates individuals voting in person for Federal office to show a government-issued photo ID or proof of US citizenship for elections after November 2010. If ID is not provided, a provisional ballot can be cast. The individual can cast a provisional ballot for the election under section 302(a) but must present required identification within 48 hours. Individuals voting other than in person must follow specific guidelines set by State or local election officials. The appropriate State or local election official may not accept any ballot for an election for Federal office provided by an individual who votes other than in person unless the individual submits a copy of a government-issued, current, and valid photo identification. The appropriate State or local election official may not accept any ballot for an election for Federal office provided by an individual who votes other than in person unless the individual submits a government-issued, current, and valid photo identification. An exception is made for overseas military voters. The identification requirement for absentee voters does not apply to overseas military voters who are absent from the US on election day. Specific identification requirements must be met for absentee voting. The Uniformed and Overseas Citizens Absentee Voting Act specifies specific identification requirements for absentee voters, including government-issued IDs and those displaying proof of US citizenship. Conforming amendments are made to Section 303 of the Act. The Uniformed and Overseas Citizens Absentee Voting Act now requires proof of US citizenship for identification issuance. Amendments are made to Section 303 of the Act. Section 303 of the Act now requires photo identification for the general election starting in November 2008 and subsequent Federal elections. During fiscal year 2008 and each succeeding fiscal year, each State must establish a program to provide free photo identifications for individuals without government-issued IDs to use for voting in elections. The program established by each State must provide free photo identifications for individuals without government-issued IDs to use for voting in elections. If a State charges a fee for the identification, it must not exceed the reasonable cost to the State, and no fee can be charged to individuals who provide an attestation. The program established by each State must provide free photo identifications for individuals without government-issued IDs to use for voting in elections. The fee charged should not exceed the reasonable cost to the State, and no fee can be charged to individuals who provide an attestation of inability to afford it. The photo identification provided under the program cannot be used for any other government purposes. The program established by each State must provide free photo identifications for individuals without government-issued IDs to use for voting in elections. The photo identification provided under the program cannot be used for any other government purposes. Payments to States will cover the costs of implementing this program. Payments will cover costs for providing photo identifications to indigent individuals for voting purposes. The Commission will make payments to States to cover costs of providing photo identifications for voting to indigent individuals who cannot afford the fee. The amount of payment will be based on the fees that would have been collected by the State under the program, as determined by information provided to the Commission. Authorization of appropriations is also included. Authorization of appropriations is granted for payments under this part for fiscal year 2008 and beyond. The amendments made by this section, including payments to cover costs of providing photo identifications for voting to indigent individuals, will take effect on October 1, 2007. Passed the House of Representatives on September 20, 2006.
